title: 109_hr4493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Emergency Management Agency Restoration Act". The Federal Emergency Management Agency is a cabinet-level independent establishment responsible for emergency preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation for all hazards. The Agency is headed by a Director appointed by the President with Senate approval, who reports directly to the President and must have extensive experience in emergency management. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is appointed for a 5-year term, with the possibility of reappointment for another 5 years. A Deputy Director is also appointed by the Director in the competitive service. The Deputy Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency must have extensive experience in emergency preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation for all hazards. Their duties include carrying out prescribed duties, serving as a liaison to the Department of Homeland Security during acts of terrorism, and acting for the Director when necessary. Law enforcement efforts to prevent terrorism are not included in the definition of emergency preparedness for this Act. The curr_chunk focuses on law enforcement efforts to prevent acts of terrorism, protect critical infrastructure, and conduct intelligence activities. The curr_chunk focuses on the transfer of functions related to law enforcement efforts to prevent acts of terrorism, protect critical infrastructure, and conduct intelligence activities. The functions, personnel, assets, and liabilities of the Department of Homeland Security relating to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, including various functions under different laws, are transferred to the Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The functions, personnel, assets, and liabilities of the Department of Homeland Security related to the Federal Emergency Management Agency are transferred to the Director of FEMA under various laws. The transition period for these transfers should be completed within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, with the Secretary of Homeland Security providing assistance as needed during this period. SEC. 4. SAVINGS PROVISIONS. Personnel Provisions: The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency may appoint officers, employees, investigators, attorneys, and administrative law judges as needed. They shall be appointed in accordance with civil service laws and compensated under title 5, United States Code. The Director can also hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding level IV pay. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency can delegate functions to designated officers and employees, including hiring experts and consultants at authorized rates for travel expenses and per diem. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency may authorize redelegations of functions as necessary. The Director can also allocate or reallocate functions among officers and establish organizational entities within the agency with prior notice to relevant committees. The Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency is authorized to prescribe rules and regulations to administer the agency's functions. Personnel, assets, liabilities, and funds related to transferred functions shall be transferred to the agency, as per section 3. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to make determinations and dispositions related to functions transferred by section 3, including personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and unexpended balances of funds. The Director shall also oversee the termination of affairs of terminated entities. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to oversee the termination of affairs of entities terminated by the Act and make necessary determinations related to personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and funds. The Act also includes provisions to ensure that personnel transferred under the Act are not separated or reduced in grade or compensation for one year after the transfer. Employees appointed in the Federal Emergency Management Agency will continue to be compensated at a rate not less than their previous position, without a break in service. Legal documents and administrative actions issued prior to the appointment will remain in effect. Legal documents and administrative actions issued by the President, Federal agencies, or courts in the performance of transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. Legal documents and administrative actions issued by the President, Federal agencies, or courts in the performance of transferred functions will remain in effect until modified or revoked by authorized officials or by law. Proceedings and applications pending before the Federal Emergency Management Agency on the date of transfers of functions under section 3 shall continue as if this section had not been enacted. The provisions of this section and section 3 do not affect suits initiated before the transfer of functions under section 3. Such suits will proceed as if this section and section 3 were not enacted. No legal actions initiated by or against the Federal Emergency Management Agency will be terminated. Any legal proceeding involving the Federal Emergency Management Agency or its officers will not be affected by the enactment of this section. Administrative actions related to regulations can continue as if this section was not enacted. References in other laws or documents pertaining to transferred functions will remain valid. (j) Repeals.--Certain provisions of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 are repealed, including Section 503(1) and Section 507.
